title: 109_hr1036
content: The Copyright Royalty Judges Program Technical Corrections Act is referred to in this Act. Any mention of a provision in title 17, United States Code, is in relation to amendments made by the Copyright Royalty and Distribution Reform Act of 2004 and the Satellite Home Viewer Extension and Reauthorization Act of 2004. Amendments to Chapter 8 of Title 17, United States Code are also included. Chapter 8 of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include provisions related to the effective date of actions taken by the Copyright Royalty Judges. Time limits for actions falling on nonbusiness days will be extended to the next business day. Amendments are made to Section 801 and Section 802 regarding the performance of actions by the Copyright Royalty Judges. The Copyright Royalty Judges may request an interpretation of substantive law from the Register of Copyrights during a proceeding. Participants can also make such requests in writing on the record, allowing for comments to minimize duplication. The Register of Copyrights must provide a written response within 14 days after receiving all briefs and comments from participants. The response will be used by the Copyright Royalty Judges for legal interpretation, but the Register cannot interpret procedural questions or make final decisions on copyright royalty rates and distribution. The Copyright Royalty Judges shall act in accordance with this title, and to the extent not inconsistent with this title, in accordance with subchapter II of chapter 5 of title 5, in carrying out the purposes set forth in section 801. The Copyright Royalty Judges must consult with copyright arbitration royalty panels for certain determinations. The Copyright Royalty Judges must consult with copyright arbitration royalty panels for certain determinations, including amendments to section 803(b) regarding publication notice requirements and filing fees. In a proceeding to determine royalty rates, a filing fee of $150 is required. In a proceeding to determine distribution of royalty fees, a filing fee is also necessary. In a proceeding to determine royalty rates or distribution of royalty fees, a filing fee of $150 is required, unless the petitioner states they will not seek more than $1000, in which case the distribution cannot exceed $1000. In paragraph (3)(A), amendments are made to the commencement of proceedings for rate adjustment and distribution of royalties. The Copyright Royalty Judges will provide a list of participants in the distribution proceeding promptly after the deadline for filing petitions. A voluntary negotiation period will be determined by the Judges. In paragraph (4)(A), the last sentence is removed. In paragraph (6)(C)(i), changes are made to clause (i). Amendments are made to the commencement of proceedings for rate adjustment and distribution of royalties. The Copyright Royalty Judges will provide a list of participants in the distribution proceeding promptly after the deadline for filing petitions. A voluntary negotiation period will be determined by the Judges. In paragraph (6)(C)(i), changes are made to clause (i) by inserting "and written rebuttal statements" after "written direct statements", striking "which may" and inserting "which, in the case of written direct statements, may", and striking "clause (iii)" and inserting "clause (iv". Amendments are made to the commencement of proceedings for rate adjustment and distribution of royalties. Following the submission of written direct and rebuttal statements, the Copyright Royalty Judges will determine a schedule for discovery. Discovery in connection with written direct statements will be allowed for 60 days, with exceptions for discovery ordered by the Judges for pending motions, orders, and disputes. Amendments are made to the procedures for rate adjustment and distribution of royalties. The Copyright Royalty Judges may order a discovery schedule for written rebuttal statements. A settlement conference will be held among participants after the 60-day discovery period. Sections 803(c)(2)(B) and 803(c)(4) are amended accordingly. Amendments are made to various sections of the Copyright Act, including changes to the approval process for the Register of Copyrights and modifications to statements of account and reports of use. Additionally, adjustments are made to section 706 of title 5 for court review and changes in section 804 regarding effective dates. Amendments are made to the Copyright Act, including changes to the approval process for the Register of Copyrights and modifications to statements of account and reports of use. Adjustments are made to section 706 of title 5 for court review and changes in section 804 regarding effective dates. In subparagraph (A), "effective date" is changed to "date of enactment", and in subparagraph (C), adjustments are made to clauses (ii) and (iii). SEC. 4. ADDITIONAL TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. Distribution of Royalty Fees under Section 111(d) of title 17, United States Code is amended to authorize the Copyright Royalty Judges for distribution to copyright owners, with deductions for administrative costs. The Copyright Royalty Judges have the discretion to authorize the Librarian of Congress to distribute amounts not in controversy during proceedings. Amendments are made to Section 114(f) of title 17, United States Code regarding sound recordings and determining reasonable proceedings under chapter 8. Proceedings under chapter 8 determine rates and terms of royalty payments for public performances of sound recordings by eligible nonsubscription transmission services and new subscription services. Rates and terms distinguish among different types of services and include a minimum fee for each type. The Copyright Royalty Judges oversee licenses for sound recordings in nonsubscription transmissions and new subscription services. Amendments are made to Section 115(c)(3) of title 17, United States Code, regarding phonorecords of nondramatic musical works. Amendments are made to Section 118 and Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, regarding noncommercial broadcasting and satellite carriers, respectively. This includes changes to subsections (b)(3) and (c) of Section 118, and subsection (b)(4) of Section 119. In Section 118 and Section 119 of title 17, United States Code, amendments are made regarding noncommercial broadcasting and satellite carriers. This involves changes to subsections (b)(3) and (c) of Section 118, and subsection (b)(4) of Section 119. The amendments include provisions for the distribution of fees to copyright owners during controversies. In subsection (c)(1)(F)(i), the word "arbitrary" is changed to "arbitration". Section 1007 of title 17, United States Code, is amended regarding digital audio recording devices. Amendments include changes to subsection (b) and (c) removing references to the Librarian of Congress. The amendments in subsection (h) of the Copyright Royalty and Distribution Reform Act of 2004 are repealed. An amendment to the effective date provision is also made. In subsection (c)(1)(F)(i), the word "arbitrary" is changed to "arbitration". Amendments are made to section 1007 of title 17, United States Code, regarding digital audio recording devices. SEC. 5. PARTIAL DISTRIBUTION OF ROYALTY FEES. Amendment allows Copyright Royalty Judges to make partial distribution of fees after receiving responses from claimants. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE. The Act and its amendments will be effective as if included in the Copyright Royalty and Distribution Reform Act of 2004, with Section 5 taking effect upon enactment of this Act.
